captions.text: I am Genarro Contaldo and this is my family dish
Its so good olive oil goes in
500 gram top side of beef you can use brisket as well its fantastic
roughly this is the size you want
mix in mix in mix in
yeah i can hear that beautiful noise.
you get two bay leafs come on im
don't just put the leaf break it
seal the meat properly i want it all like this one onion
don't worry if its not too thin the onions will dissolve it come and have a look get inside
wine goes in the wine you drink
do not use the cooking one come on what is it cooking wine
its almost dancing inside let the wine
i want the onions to sweat
not to burn do you know what the difference between sweat
you need a bit of exercise
what you do when your jogging you sweat that is sweat
burn you go to a holiday
anywhere round the world including italy
you stand under the sun for two hours or three hours and you burn
you don't want to do that
they kiss each other when they go all in
remember its still on a high flame
put about half a glass of wine
fill it up with water two three
when it starts to do that lovely bunch of
slowly slowly for about two hours
i remember my mom when she used to do this for a sunday lunch
come and have a look inside come on this is the
which goes well with perfect tagliatelle
if you want to see me how i make this tagliatelle click the link now
look at that as soon as i put the pasta inside it started
yes the smell brings my memory back
when you kiss with the parmesan on top like
a bride and groom throwing confetti on the top
drizzle of oil and just enjoy
it so delicious do you want some
if you want to see more of my fantastic recipes from the Almalfi coast click
to see the latest recipe from Jamie Olivers food tube channels
it is very easy love you

comments.author: Callum Jones

comments.text:
This man has actually changed me. Of all the amazing chefs and videos we 
get to watch on youtube, Gennaro's infectious personality has meant he is 
the only one who got me to stop with the easy junk food route and start 
cooking some of these delicious recipes. It does so much for your health 
and your mental wellbeing when you can cook something that you or your 
loved one can enjoy.﻿

comments.author: ariean rachmat

comments.text:
There's another ragu video he's one, but the recipe is a little different 
from this one.  Why's that?

I also don't understand why you need to dissolve tomato paste in wine 
before adding it to the pot.  I've never heard of needing to dissolve 
tomato paste.  I've always seen it just thrown right in with everything 
else.﻿
comments.author: kommisar

comments.text:
exactly but I always used stock. In this particular recipee that water is 
better imo
comments.author: Chris Capozzi

comments.text:
+Chris Capozzi
Water is added to these kinds of sauces so as to prevent them from being 
reduced too much.  If you didn't add water, it would basically be a paste 
in the end.
comments.author: kommisar

comments.text:
+Luca Gasperini I have always made a Bolonese with ground veal , pork , and 
beef. For a Napolitano I make it the way Gennaro does. This recipee is 
unbelievable. I never add water to my sauces until I tried this. It changes 
the consistency and reduces down. Makes it much lighter with the heavy cuts 
of meat.
comments.author: Chris Capozzi

comments.text:
+kommisar I'd say that ragu is generally a tomato sauce with meat. For 
example this recipe is different from the famous "ragu alla bolognese" that 
should be made, among other things, with minced meat.
comments.author: Luca Gasperini

comments.text: +Y0GI B3AR water adds zero flavor , stock or wine increase flavor.
comments.author: phibber

comments.text: +Mark Bloggs Ohh, right, well it makes sense now haha, thanks :)
comments.author: Y0GI B3AR

comments.text:
+Y0GI B3AR could do.  but the wine is going in anyway as one of the 
ingredients so it's efficient to do it like that.
comments.author: Mark Bloggs

comments.text: +STU08087 But why cant you dissolve it in water?
comments.author: Y0GI B3AR

comments.text:
I am guessing the family one is more suitable for children as it has no 
garlic or chillies.
comments.author: Mark Bloggs

comments.text:
+STU08087
Gotcha.
comments.author: kommisar

comments.text:
it just avoids pockets of tomato paste should you not stir it enough - in a 
large pot with a lot of large pieces of meat, it can be difficult to 
circulate and stir the tomato paste into all areas - dissolved in wine, a 
lighter liquid - it can easily circulate into the rest of the sauce
comments.author: STU08087

comments.author: The Radz

comments.text: Won't the meat overcook?﻿
comments.author: John Carry

comments.text:
+John Carry the meats used are tough cuts. They require long cooking time 
to break down, turns a soft almost gelatinous texture. Opposite type of 
meat used, for example, than prime cuts, which are a quick fry, like steak. 
If you tried this with an eye fillet then you would indeed end up with 
livery overcooked meat.
comments.author: dragon2712

comments.text:
on a low gas and immersed in sauce it's fine.  it's more of a danger when 
you are roasting meat in the oven as, although on a low gas it can start to 
go dry.
comments.author: Mark Bloggs

comments.text:
In slow cooking the longer you cook the meat the better. You use the cheap 
fatty meat cuts and after several hours of cooking they melt in your mouth 
(literally)

comments.text: Meat cant overcook in ragu

comments.author: schwaggbagYES

comments.text:
So Gennaro, Jamie, I made this dish last weekend- I have been deep into 
traditional italian cooking for many years. The only modifications I did 
were that I used Chianti wine, san marzano tomatoes, bucatini noodles and 
dried oregano (taken from the stem) in the sauce. Just amazing- really 
worth making. That slow cooking really pays off with all the meat falling 
apart.

http://i1117.photobucket.com/albums/k584/agraham11/10931283_10155114617270007_1223347249773975834_n_zpslasbex2c_1.jpg

 ﻿
